keyTakeAways: US President Donald Trump has threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombia, accusing President Gustavo Petro of promoting drug production.

Colombia is the United States' largest trading partner in Latin America, with 30% of Colombian exports going to the US; a tariff increase could severely impact key exports like coffee, flowers, gold, and fruits.
Colombian citizens express anxiety about economic consequences, such as job losses, company bankruptcies, and reduced access to US visas for families abroad.

President Gustavo Petro has previously criticized US actions on drug trafficking and migration, including calling for criminal proceedings over US strikes on drug-smuggling boats and speaking at a pro-Palestinian demonstration in New York.
The US has revoked Petro’s visa after his pro-Palestinian remarks, highlighting the diplomatic tensions between the two nations.
The US provides about $450 million annually in economic and military assistance to Colombia for anti-drug efforts, which could be cut if Trump’s threats are enacted.
Colombian public figures, including taxi drivers, university students, and retirees, express frustration over the leaders’ confrontational rhetoric and its impact on everyday citizens.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombians are experiencing growing anxiety as US President Donald Trump threatens to impose tariffs and cut aid to Colombia, accusing President Gustavo Petro of promoting drug production. The feud, fueled by public statements and historical tensions over drug trafficking and migration policies, threatens Colombia’s economy—its largest trading partner is the US, with 30% of exports dependent on American markets. Citizens fear job losses, business bankruptcies, and reduced visa access. Petro has previously challenged US actions, including revoking his own visa after a pro-Palestinian speech. Both leaders are criticized for their confrontational rhetoric, with many Colombians emphasizing that drug trafficking remains a persistent, unresolved problem affecting daily life.
title: Colombians caught in fallout of Trump-Petro feud
